qas.question: If a lead wasn't soldered manually, what device was used?
Which type of PCB construction technique was used first?
In through-hole construction, what are the leads on the front attached to on the back?
For boards with two sides, to what angle are leads bent to in order to install them horizontally?
What is improved by bending leads in opposite directions on the back of double-sided PCBs?

plausible_answers.text: by bending the leads 90 degrees in the same direction

qas.question: Vertical installation of through-hole parts with two axial leads in done how?
Vertical installation is done by bending the leads what degrees?
Leads have to be soldered in what way?
A wave sewing machine can solder the what?

context: The first PCBs used <a1_0>through-hole<a1_0/> technology, mounting electronic components by leads inserted through holes on one side of the board and soldered onto <a2_0>copper traces<a2_0/> on the other side. Boards may be single-sided, with an unplated component side, or more compact double-sided boards, with components soldered on both sides. Horizontal installation of through-hole parts with two axial leads (such as resistors, capacitors, and diodes) is done <b5_0>by bending the leads <a3_0><b6_0>90<b6_0/> degrees<a3_0/> in the same direction<b5_0/>, inserting the part in the board (often bending leads located on the back of the board in opposite directions to improve the part's <a4_0>mechanical strength<a4_0/>), soldering the leads, and trimming off the ends. <b8_0>Leads<b8_0/> may be soldered either <b7_0>manually<b7_0/> or by a <a0_0>wave soldering machine<a0_0/>.
